content:
Hello there We have read the question We try to help

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/xpunge/?src=ss

U wrote me that : The program had no Trashfolder /trashcan .

The program Thunderbird has a the option ,that is that there is the option to select in the serversettings to place after some configuration the option to have deleted message automatically removed them to a new trashfolder that Thunderbird is automaticly bringing up with that and also is placing a traditional trashcan icone in the program itself. Using the IMAP protocol is oke, if you do not use that and you do use a pop account switch over to IMAP if ,if that is possible if you become to choose it to like having that option to have that ,and like to create it with these next steps in the software.

Go to the account settings after that then go to the serversettings and use that option to place a deleted message direct in to that trashfolder.After taking use of that option Thunderbird wil automaticly create for you a trashcan. The trashcan is back and problems are solved .


Greetings Firefox volunteer

content:
Prova a fare queste operazioni di manutenzione:

  1. Fare un backup integrale del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  2. Compattare le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  3. Riavviare Thunderbird
  4. Se il problema non è risolto, ricostruire l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
  5. Riavviare Thunderbird

content: A possibility is that thunderbird could not locate the profile after update if there was any interference, such as from antivirus or VPN. If so, the old profile may still be there. to investigate, do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - you are now in the profile in windows file explorer, click back one folder so you will be in the 'profiles' folder. - here, if there is another profile, it should be listed. An IMAP account would be in the imapmal folder and a POP account would be in the Mail folder - if it looks right, then, in thunderbird, do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' - now, click the 'create profile' button - click next - now, enter a short name for the profile, such as, OLDPROFILE and then click the 'choose' button and locate and select the profile you want, then click finish and launch.
creator: davidsk

content: The message indicates that the receiving server has disallowed the attachment. You might try zipping the file prior to sending. This is not a Thunderbird issue.

content:
So far, using Filtaquilla Header Regex, I created 2 filters:

One to cover the case with a Cc field The Header Regex is the same for From: To: and Cc: fields /^(?:[a-zA-Z0-9._%+-]+@domain\.tld|[A-Za-z\s]+<[a-zA-Z0-9._%+-]+@domain\.tld>)(?:\s*,\s*(?:[a-zA-Z0-9._%+-]+@domain\.tld|[A-Za-z\s]+<[a-zA-Z0-9._%+-]+@domain\.tld>))*$/gi

One to cover the case without Cc field In this case the Regex is used for From: and To: fields And I have an additional rule checking that the Cc field does not contain "@" (using Mozilla standard rule)

Any clue?
creator: bartounet

content: Oh, I just realised I should use "sender:" "recipients:" and "ccList:" instead of "From:" "To:" and "Cc:"

content:
If you copy the messages to a temporary folder, it's possible to export them to a single text file, which you can then attach to a new message. The export requires the ImportExportTools NG add-on.

You could also attach multiple messages by drag and drop from the message list to a new message.
creator: sfhowes

content:
If the old computer is still available, I recommend redoing the transfer: TRANSFER::: Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

On your question, yes you can restore a local folder: - install the addon, importexporttools NG - highlight 'Local Folders' - rightclick and select importexport option to import mbox and then locate and select a folder you want to import - repeat the above for each such folder
creator: davidsk

creator: davidsk

content: The group lists would have been in the profile, so I assume your restore did not include the full profile. Not knowing how you created and retrieved the backup, my suggestion is to exit thunderbird and then copy all files beginning with 'abook' from the backup to the current profile. If unsure how to locate profile, do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - now, exit thunderbird - in the open directory, you will see one or more files beginning with 'abook'. now, copy the 'abook' files from backup to overwrite these files. I think that is your best best to regain the lost lists.
creator: davidsk

content: It takes some work. None of this is due to Thunderbird, but due to email accounts. My response will not address everything you want but may be a start: - for Gmail, rightclick on account, an click 'subscribe' and UNsubscribe from Allmail and Important. Doing that will cut your cpu time and reduce disk space noticably, as that was duplicating all your receives and sends for Gmail. Also, after doing that, exit thunderbird, locate the allmail, allmail.msf, important,important.msf files in your profile and delete them - for Gmail, click server settings then the 'advanced' button and enter [Gmail} (including the brackets) in the IMAP server directory field - for the duplicated file names, check to see which one the oniine account prefers (e.g., on the bt.com site, delete a message and see into which folder it went). Then, in thunderbird, set the delete folder to that folder and then delete the other. This may take a bit of practice because thunderbird provides default names and the actual account may prefer a different one. For unwanted folders, if you cannot delete from within thunderbird, try doing it when thunderbird is not running.
creator: davidsk

Hai un backup recente del profilo?

Inoltre, Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
